title: 149 rare classic cars, performance vehicles up for sale in largest US Marshals auction
text:
CLOSE

Had your sights set on a Pontiac Firebird Trans Am like the one driven by Burt Reynolds in the film, "Smokey and the Bandit"?

Or perhaps a Ford Mustang from the 1960s?

Those cars are among 149 classic, performance and luxury vehicles being sold off by the U.S. marshals in their largest-ever auction involving a single owner.

The cars are part of a federal civil case involving the owners of DC Solar, husband and wife Jeff and Paulette Carpoff, who are accused of running a Ponzi scheme, according to the Los Angeles Times. Their company is now defunct.

“It is rare for the U.S. Marshals to hold an auction of such a stunning collection of vehicles,” Chief Deputy U.S. Marshal Lasha Boyden of the agency's Sacramento, California, office said in a statement.

The U.S. Marshals are auctioning 149 classic, luxury and performance cars, with some seen here during a preview in Sacramento, California. The vehicles came from the owners of the defunct DC Solar Company. (Photo: Shane T. McCoy/U.S. Marshals)

Among the gems is the 1978 Pontiac Firebird Trans Am, which Reynolds once owned.

The auction, which is being conducted by Apple Auctioneering Co., is already underway in Woodland, California, with pre-bidding occurring online.
